>>17475129
Of course spraying random chemicals on your skin isn't healthy. Many people actively manage to do more damage to their bodies in other ways, though, without even knowing. Classic case would be nitrosamines from preparing food, general inactivity in the daily life as well as unprotected exposure to sun. Fragrances and cosmetics in general are highly regulated and the ingredients which are linked to negative effects are taken out. Stuff like BHT will certainly be the next ban.
It is the natural progress, as humans get capable of becoming older and older, the "next thing that kills you" will always be found. It might be that perfumes cause negative effects if you use them for 150 years, but alas, we aren't getting that old yet. It might also be possible that it only takes 80 years, has manifested in a few cases but they couldn't be linked to perfumes (or nobody has made the link yet). The only way to completely avoid this is by eliminating as many chemicals from your daily life as possible.
I'm a chemist and the juice that probably has started to kill me was all the stuff I already had to breathe in in the past. It won't be fragrances for me, I will expire before that. So I apply 40 sprays.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17476405
It depends on both the fragrance and the bottle size/atomizer, people often ignore the latter as a variable, and they really shouldn’t

For my ADG Profumo (closest thing I have to a signature scent), I really try not to push it beyond three full sprays because it’s some strong shit and the 75ml atomizer does a good job. However, my little tester bottle of Montblanc Explorer (not exactly a weak frag) probably takes a good 7-9 full pumps to get enough on me because the atomizer fucking sucks for some reason

At the end of the day, try not to microanalyze these things. Find your own balance in terms of the specific frags you have and how well they work on you. There’s no one size fits all approach to any of this, I find whenever I get a new frag it takes some genuine trial and error to figure out what’s going on

>>17474148
This is completely wrong.
pre-natal T affects primarily brain development in the embryo and in infancy, especially high or low T in the womb is associated with abnormal sexual development and alternative gender identities
post-natal T affects physical characteristics after puberty.
regular T affects muscle growth, bone growth, fertility, and sex drive
the DHT metabolite (other major form of T in humans) affects genital growth, hair growth (balding on the head, body hair growth), and is the key male neurosteroid, driving behaviors like aggression and competition.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17476610
Since the boots are new and you don't know how long they've been on the shelf and what were the conditions in which they were stored, you might want to at least give them a light conditioning. Get a shoe brush, horsehair recommended, and brush the boots. After that get a drop of conditioning on your fingertips and spread it evenly over the boot, get more drops as needed. Leave the boots rest for fifteen minutes to an hour so the leather will soak in the conditioner. Brush lightly again and use a cotton cloth to wipe off lightly any residue or area that looks too greasy. The leather should feel supple and slightly oily to the touch afterwards. Not dry nor moist.
Afterwards, a light brushing after every wear should be more than enough to keep the boots in shape. Condition again when the leather feels or looks dry.

posts.com: Alright /wt/, anon with the wacky, colorful shitters here. I’ve made another irresponsible purchase and require a good hazing from you fine gentlemen. While I’ve enjoyed my time buying unserviceable shitters for the price of a night out at the movies, Ive been wanting to put on my big boi pants and upgrade to serviceable shitters, with an emphasis on Made in USA/assembled in USA/an Amerifat sharted on it at some point timepieces, and this will be my first step into the format…

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17478327
Let’s address the elephant in the room: everything about the watch is retarded. There’s no denying that. It would make a terrible one watch collection. But if you are, say, an anon with a whole collection of wacky shitters who enjoys a lil nonsense, well this makes for a decent addition to the collection.
It’s a Timex from the American Documents line, which is unique in that they’re the only sub 2k watch I could find that have ANY parts made in the US, not including watches with the Ameriquartz movement, which this doesn’t use for no good reason (instead it’s a Ronda, in reference to the hit single “Help Me Rhonda” by America’s band The Beach Boys, surely). The case, hands, dial, strap and mineral glass (in this case, Gorilla Glass) are all made and sourced from the US of A. I think the case and hands are done by an industrial company that doesn’t even make watch parts. I also believe Timex had to convert some spare room into an assembly room for this series. Kinda neat for a Dutch holding company.
What makes this particular model extra unique is that it’s a collaboration with the apparel company MadeWorn, aka some tatted up hipster who fucks up shirts by hand with a blowtorch and sandpaper then charges 200 bucks for it. He also did those custom engraved Rolex abominations you might have seen pictures of floating around the net. Apparently each case, hand and dial are uniquely fucked up, making no two the same.
Pretty neat if you can look past the astronomical price they were originally asking for: 850 smackers, with an original American Documents going for 500. It would take a ridiculous deal for me to satisfy my curiosity for the piece, which is exactly what happened. Timex got me once with a 60% off (rare even for them) Coca Cola Timex Q that I quite like, and they got me again with a very tempting pre tax price tag it 340, less than their currently on sale normal ADs which are at 400 atm, lol…

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17478331
Obviously these weren’t hot sellers. No surprise, as it’s a dress watch that you can’t use in most dressy situations, and a beater with only 30m water resistance. It would take a specific type of retard to be happy with this shitter…
Anyways, onto the watch itself.
>Negatives
Previously mentioned water resistance/formal impracticality
24hr am/pm gmt dial when there’s no gmt hand to be found (AVGN: WHAT WERE THEY THINKING)
Black hands on a half black dial make it very impractical in low light
The hands are split asymmetrically down the middle so it’ll look the hour hand is behind by a couple minutes sometimes, depending on the angle (ocd anons need not apply)
…and you thought fauxtina was obnoxious
>Positives
It’s neato
Ignoring the quirks, the dial is one of Timex’s best
I can’t emphasize enough how unusual a made in USA body is, especially for sub 2k (besides, say, the occasional dude who will make custom Casio cases for 200 hundy and sell them off Instagram)
Very nice, comfortable suede strap from S B Boot Tanning, the dudes that do leather for Red Wing Boots
The finishing is pleasant for what it’s going for, and again, an Amerishart hand finishing something for a watch this cheap is non existent (even if the finishing is more like “fucking up”)
Initial complaints of scratch marks on the other AD watch hands is a non issue here
Initial complaints of the AD watches looking boring is a non issue here
Nice brass case back and crown
Reminds me of Adventureland in Disneyland

Conclusion: I can understand why every sane watch collector and insane member of /wt/ would hate it or simply dismiss it as a costume watch to wear as a steampunk cosplayer to Comic Con. In many ways, you’re correct. On the other hand, it’s a piece that is too weird to live, too rare to die. Thank you for reading my blogpost.
Now please, if you will, roast the shitter to your hearts content.

>Hiking
Get some lace-to-toe leather boots instead of combat boots. Your feet will thank you. The ability to choose the lacing the whole way up the foot is a huge plus.

There's something deeply ironic about posts like this.
Basically what it's saying is: STOP CARING WHAT PEOPLE THINK AND JUST DRESS LIKE YOU WANT!
This is framed as some kind of personal growth, as if disregarding societal norms and etiquette somehow makes you more mature when this is mostly done by teenagers and children.

It's also framed as an expression of individuality, yet OP's pic is something straight out of TikTok fed to him directly from the algorithm that has already profiled him as someone who likes that kind of content. Literally dressing like the chinese app is telling you too.

OP and this poster are just NPCs going through their late adolescence ,thinking that other adults have 'boring ass clothes' when in fact those people have already probably went through their extravagant clothing phase and grown out of it like most adults do.


In conclusion, it's funny that you believe that you are being 'yourself' by doing exactly what millions of teenagers are doing guided by a chinese algorithm feeding you your 'unique' taste

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17475977
There's a difference between "disregarding societal norms and etiquette" and having an alternative fashion sense. And yes, I'd say being yourself regardless of what or how anyone else perceives you is mature. Yes, overcoming fear and gaining confidence in yourself and your convictions is absolutely a "personal growth". Would you rather covet your passions and interests and be miserable, rather than get a couple of odd looks here and there?

OP isn't dressing like that because some "chinese app is telling him to", he wants to dress like that because he's seen it and he likes it. When people see something that they like and that resonates with them then they'll obviously indulge themselves in it. It's no different than seeing fashion in a magazine or on television. You're acting like OP is being held against his will to dress that way, no, they literally said they "really like" how it looks.

I don't doubt that older people went through extravagant fashion senses in their youth and I never said they did. Nor does that change the fact that they wear boring clothes now. I'm simply telling OP not to deny himself the opportunity to do something he wants, especially when you're in your adolescence, it's a time to enjoy yourself and discover what you like.

So by your definition, to be "yourself" you have to be entirely original. Regardless of if you whole heartedly enjoy how it looks and enjoy wearing it, that's not being "yourself", simply because it's popular? It sounds to me like you can't stand seeing a multiple people sharing the same interest in fashion. It also seems have a problem with the app tiktok more than anything, rather than OP actually finding a fashion sense he likes.

I haven't seen such a genuinely retarded post like this on here in ages.

Dress how you like OP, I do and it feels great, don't let spergs like this discourage you.

You need reasonably thick hair with a decent amount of volume. Then get it cut in layers. Just go to a hairdressers or stylist, ask for your hair to be layered and show the the picture. HELL NO.

No piece of clothing is worth half of your savings. These clothes are for rich people. They are for people who see 2 grand how you see 20 dollars.

As other anons have mentioned, look for cheaper alternatives. Get one used, get a similar fitting blazer for cheaper. Like i get it. Theres this weird yearning for it. Like, you want to own a high end piece of clothing and have it/treasure it but once you buy the blazer and the effect wears off after a week it will just be another jacket you own and wear like once per month. You will have a 2000 dollar piece of material regret in your closet and will look back on your decision to buy it in a year as a huge retarded mistake. Also believe me, and this may not matter to you but absolutely nobody will able to tell that your 2 grand jacket isnt just some other jacket from the thrift store but you. You wont get compliments on it, you wont get people thinking you're effay, its just a loose fitting black blazer. It isnt a statement piece, you're paying for the materials and the fit. Like i said, these are rich people clothes.

I swear this place, insta and fashion yt channels rot people's brain to the point where they make decisions like this and think they can justify making absolutely retarded purchases.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17475533
There arent any good pieces of clothing in vintage stores here in the uk. The european high quality stuff is expensive here, the american high quality stuff is expensive here and the uk manufactured stuff is all fast fashion tat.

Its all overpriced stinky ralph lauren and tommy hillfiger shirts, a few old levis jeans sprinkled in with a couple of old gildan jumpers with some 'retro' print on them. There aren't actually any high or even any mid tier fashion brands found in thrift stores. Everything of value is on ebay or grailed and seems to hold it's value. USA has relatively high quality heritage outdoor brands like carhartt, filson, patagonia, penfield, columbia, nautica (to an extent) as well as the skater brands like stussy that can be found at bottom dollar at thrift stores. Here in the UK that stuff is imported and seems to hold it's value a lot more in stores. You'll see a thrift store selling some 'vintage' champion hoody for like 30gbp+ over here as a standard. For that kind of money you can just get a new hoody.

I find the best way to find bargains for high end brands is go to ebay and search for lesser known high-mid fashion brands and filter to ending soonest. I open Mr porter, go through their brandlist and just copy/paste a lot of them in to ebay and see what comes up. The more popular stuff like apc, norse projects, fjallraven goes for quite a bit (although it does go for cheap sometimes) but you'll get some lesser known brand for nearly nothing with the quality still being very good. Like you can end up getting a 200+gbp jumper or jacket regularly for 1/10th of the price.

>>17476868
Because higher end brands dont touch china with a barge pole. You're better off just buying a good brand used.

Clothes are something where people subconsciously pick up on quality. Like if you're wearing some cheap shitty chinese pants like those irl people will pick up on the shade of beige they are, which will be too bright and slightly off, it won't look natural. They will pick up on how thin they are, and how that thin material sits on you (thicker materials tend to bunch up differently and look better) how they fit on you, the design. They just wont look as good on you. People wont pick this up consciously but they will just instinctively feel it. It will just look like you're wearing some cheap boomer pants.

I actually have a pair of norse projects chinos and a cheaper pair of primark chinos of the same style. And in person the difference is night and day. You see how the chinos fold and bunch up nicely in the photo? They wont do that in real life because the material is paper thin. You wont be able to roll them up like that and have them look good due to this as well. I have already mentioned the colour difference, the finish on them will look cheap and grandma-like (back pockets will be for show, stitching in side of the leg will look like shit etc).

chinks are masters at using misleading/fake pics but you cant judge clothes from pictures.

>>17474926
How old do you look like? If you want to stay loyal to your style while simultaneously looking younger you can mix things up a bit by dressing down the formality in a creative way.
I had the same problem when I was around your age, and the solution that helped me most was to play a little bit with different colors. Keep the overall look and only exchange one or two Items for a more casual versions of it. E.g when wearing something similar like the overcoat in your pic related (only in grey), I switched the blue chinos for yellow or even red ones and was wearing casual button down shirts instead of dress-shirts. Switching shoes or even shoelaces for more casual versions also helps a lot. I often got compliments back then on how I managed to mix youth and formality. Just play around a little bit with what looks good on you and what doesn't. But be careful, the difference between a good outfit and looking like a clown can be quite small if you do this.

Wear a plain nice t-shirt/polo/henley/etc and strap on some suspenders over them. If you’re going long sleeves then roll up the sleeves to your forearms. Make sure you have form-fitting pants but not formal dress pants. Shoes can be fashion sneakers or low boots. The key is to preserve a sophisticated look (some of which you might already have in your wardrobe) without going over the top. Works better when you have an athletic build

For me, it's the DW 8000. The best gshock watch. I even ask for extra light and the watch is so friendly and more than willing to oblige.

One time I asked for light and a buffalo skull appeared. I said, "Wow, time to get tough!" and the nice friendly DW 8000 lit up and read, "Time to get Tough".

Now the watch greets me with "Time to get Tough" and ALWAYS give me light. It's such a fun and cool accessory with my current outfits, I wear it at least 3 times a week for hitting the gym and going on a run, 1-2 times for casual fits on the weekend, and maybe once for dressing up when I'm in a rush but want a great watch that is stylish, tough, and can resist shocks.

I even dip my DW 8000 in the ocean, it's water resistant! What a great watch.

Is there a way to buff scratches out of the displays of F91Ws and the like? I have a practically brand new F105W with a big nasty gouge on the display that I got on it a week after getting it, and I haven't used it since. What would work well? Baking soda? Brasso? Polywatch?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17478133
You have crippling autism.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17478136
Depends how deep the scratch or gouge is. If its a light scratch yeah something lightly abrasive in a paste like polywatch should work. If the gouge is bad you have to remove all of the undamaged material down to the depth of the scratch evenly. Theres a lot of videos on youtube that include using polywatch on a non-sapphire crystal, even with a badly scratched crystal it can 'improve' it and with light scratches it can make it nearly new again so you don't have to fully replace it and disassemble the watch.

On the other hand, its a $21 watch, I wouldn't recommend spending $7 on polywatch and probably an hour working on the watch. Just buy a new one and use the scratched one as a hard beater you no longer care about.

>>17469373
>Sport coats

If you've never gotten into them before, either have a friend measure you or paid a tailor 20 bucks to do it. I'd go to the tailor because you're going to probably need to build a relationship with one eventually

Here are the measurements you need in descending importance:

1 Shoulders
2 Chest
3 Waist
4 Sleeves

Shoulders will fuck your fit up and can not be adjusted. Remind yourself of this dozens of times. If your shoulders are 18", you can wear sport coats that are 18-19". Anything too small won't fit, and anything too large will look awful and you can't really cheat around it by adding bulky layers either.

Chest and waist are way easier to work with, if it's a couple inches big they can be taken in. I am cheap and want to avoid the tailor because I am also lazy so I am for sport coats that have a few inches drop between chest and west to emphasize my torso and make me look less like a sack of potatoes. If my chest is 45, I want my waist on the coat to be 41-42. Nothing massive because I'm not in great shape.
Note that this isn't my actual waist, that's a 36.

Sleeves are normally easy to deal with. If they are too long, hem them. If they are a little short don't panic, there's normally an inch built in for adjustment.

Once you have those measurements it's just a matter of patience on eBay. Search for your chest, and then match your measurements from the tailor with the measurements provided by the seller.

>>17469555
>Haha, i like them billowy like that. Its just a full cut, not the wrong size - the neck, armholes, and cuffs fit well.

For the record, that can still be the wrong size. I'm the guy giving sport coat sizing advice, didn't want to go into too much at once and make things more complicated than needed but here's so more info:

My chest is 42", but my neck is 16.5" and it's snug at 16.5. My sleeve length is 36. So if I blindly buy a 16.5x36 dress shirt, the body often billows because my powerful lizard like neck is meant to be with a size 46 to 48 shirt for the chest measurement.

I'm 6'3 and about 215, but even when I was 150 and so much hotter my neck size was still the same. What to do?

1: Buy shirts from retailers like Charles Tyrwhitt that let you choose "cuts". I get a 16.5x36 extra slim. That way my neck isn't choked, but the torso is thinner and so are the sleeves

2: Buy a shirt that fits torso and use collar extenders. It's basically an invisible button with an elastic loop that you attach to your collar button, increases the collar size by an inch. If you're wearing a tie, it's invisible. If you're not wearing a tie, don't button the top button, and then you're fine.

3: Made to measure shirts. This is where I'm gravitating towards now that I get the process and know where to go. This way the shirt will be designed to fit you perfectly

Ok here's where it gets dicey. Oftentimes when we have someone who strongly inspires us, the urge is to copy them as much as possible. Imitation is flattering, etc. The problem is a lot of people in the beginning of their style evolution didn't stop to think "Will this look as good on me as it does him?" And of equal importance "Do I have to the money to buy what I need to look good?"

I went to his insta and his look doesn't seem to revolve around items that fit a certain way, which is good. That way you can copy elements whether you have the same body as him or not. Do me a favor, go to his Instagram and pic out any fit there, then we're going to see what you could take from it and make your own without looking like you're trying to cosplay him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17477873
As the other guy said, buy longer jeans and have them hemmed. As a short guy that needs a 27" inseam, this is a frequent and cheap alteration, like $10.
There's an advantage to this - the rise of pants increases proportionally to the inseam. IE, longer inseams have higher rises because the manufacturer assumes the wearer is taller. So when you buy long jeans and hem them, you get a higher rise than normal, which makes your torso appear shorter and your legs longer. Which makes you look taller and more proportionate.

Let’s not get lost in the weeds. First off I think you have to be more specific, and carve just the northeast portion off the USA and compare only that part to the UK. Otherwise it’s not a fair comparison at all because the rest of the country is a mess fashion wise, and yes that ESPECIALLY includes LA and Miami (you can’t buy class). With that out of the way, the UK is still the clear winner. Hopefully this doesn’t offend American anons, but I think it’s just because the USA is a younger country and hasn’t reached the same level of civilization yet. American style is simple and utilitarian. Think Ralph Lauren, Brooks Brothers etc. This is actually more aligned with my own personal style. Old Europe is just gay to me. America hasn’t gone through as many cycles of decadence as older countries have. I think this is changing and you can see it in things like the craft beer trend, “foodie culture”, and increased wine and quality cheese production in the USA. Previously, Americans only ate to survive and wore clothes to cover their nakedness and not an ounce of thought went into the details beyond this. There was important work to do.
In contrast, the UK has been doing this fashion stuff for a while. Look at how swagged out Henry the 8th was, pic related, and then compare that to boring old George Washington’s dress. Yes he was a royal but even British working class scum are more fashion conscious than their lowly counterparts across the pond. See the tidy and thoughtfully curated fits of the skinheads, or the expensive wardrobes of the ‘casuals’ soccer hooligan subculture…
